reviewText:
tl;dr version:  It's not fun, nor is it particularly tactical.

There are so many things wrong with the beginning of this game that it makes me completely uninterested in continuing to see if it ever gets better.  Your main melee units can't be controlled.  They just swing randomly at the nearest dude, which is almost always not who you want them to attack.  Your units can only move in straight lines, so attempting to get more than one guy on the same target is a chore.  Your units permanently die, which is kind of neat, but you don't have any method of healing them, so its really up to the random number generator instead of any sort of tactical play that determines if you preserve your guys.  The maps have random areas where you simply can't walk, for no apparent reason, that is very difficult to notice, so your flanking maneuvers are further frustrated by magical impassive terrain.

Also, the writing is bad and plot flimsy.  The graphics are about twenty years out of date, which I knew going into the game, but still disappointing.  The background noise often sounds like someone chewing for some reason, which is kind of gross to listen to on a 10 second repeat loop.

I've requested a refund.  It's not worth the $4.

reviewText:
I played this game on Desura a while back and its nice to see it come to Steam with achevements.

This is an old school game; a throw-back to when preperation and strategy meant more than quick reflexes.

Age of Fear 2 takes the tried and true turn based hex battle system and removes the hexes.  You must choose carefully when and where to move units on the battlefield and try to keep them grouped together to be sucessful.  The enemy AI is quick to pick off that lone wolf in your army marching ahead of the crowd.  No leading the way with mages and archers unless of course you WANT them to die.  The mages are the most fun to play with all the different spells they offer but you dont want to get them anywhere near the front lines.  You will be forced to shield them with cheap melee units as most battles will have enemies comming from different directions.  Oh and the AI knows this, they will come after your frail units and even knows to move its ranged units away from the front lines.  The AI is competent in this game and will offer you a challenge.

Graphicly this game is not going to blow you away, but its not supposed to.  Its uses overhead 2D graphics system, which is pretty much the only downside to the game.  Its just a bit bland in that department and you can see that pretty easily from the screenshots. The game shines elsewhere and it shows in its balance and depth of strategy.

The sound effects and voice acting are basic, but the music is pretty darn good.

There are two campains with a dozen or so missions each.  The story is fairly long delivered via text between battles.
Your units (if they survive battles) can gain experience and level up or upgrade.  If they do die you can hire new units between battles.  This type of game isnt for everyone but true strategy fans will certainly have plenty to sink their teeth into.

reviewText:
Age of Fear 2 is quite similar to Age of Fear, just with different units and campaigns, so for the most part my review of AoF applies here: It is, at its core, a turn-based tactical game about small unit battles similar in feel to Battle for Wesnoth. It has some RPG elements and a unifying story for each campaign, along with the occasional text adventure-like choice to make. The battle system is strong and well balanced. The game is not hex-based and allows for free movement. It takes a bit to get used to how you can effectively use melee units to block access to your ranged/spellcaster units, but once you get the hang of it, it is a thing of beauty.

As a single-player game I found it a bit short; I finished the campaign in about 15 hours on Normal. I would have liked to see more content; I enjoyed each aspect of the game (the battles, the ongoing campaign, text choices, unit recruitment and development, building up my heroes with items and such) but felt that I really wanted to see more of each. The concept and elements came together well, but I was left wanting more. I bought it on a Steam sale and was very pleasantly surprised with it. Enough so that I went back and purchased the first AoF (which is being updated along with AoF2) at full price.

Another reason I feel that this game is worth purchasing is the dedication of the developers. Upon posting in the hardly-used steam discussion group about a problem with the game, I was contacted within hours about my issue. The lead developer had a patch up on Steam to address my issue within an hour of getting further information from me. He then sent me an extra copy of the game to give to a friend for my trouble. They clearly are dedicated to constantly improving the game and making players happy. That kind of customer service is rare in this industry.

reviewText:
TLDR: Sequel to an excellent but minimalist strategy RPG. Some micromanagement. Challenging.

AOF is a turn based strategy RPG. It's not grid  based like other SRPGs, however your units have individual stats that you  manage throughout the gameplay in order to defeat more and more difficult opponents.

Cons:
-No multiplayer matchmaking system, but has too few players/exposure.
-The graphics might be an issue for some. For me, I had a lot of fun. Like they say, don't judge a book by it's cover. This game is deep and can be difficult.
-The girl from the trailer is not in it.

Pros:
-Unit management and advancement requires you to make smart choices in order to survive. You may get to the point where if you've made poor choices, you can't go any further or you lose the level and have to go  back to a last save.
-Good story. A little minimalist, but again, this game is all about the game play.
-Varied and balanced unit compositions. You won't get to the last level and not lose a guy. You WILL be challenged.

Go check out a video and see if you can get past the visuals. If you're a strategy gamer you won't regret buying it.

reviewText:
A hidden gem for any TBS fan.

Two campaigns of ca. 15 battles each interspaced with some of the most amusing storyline (very much tongue in check, in a refreshing manner) will definitely return your moneys worth.

In the beginning your troops will die and any single one you manage to rescue into the next stage is cherished. The longer they live, the better they become. Towards the end they are nigh unstoppable, but that is when you can increase the difficulty to even the odds (I did).

I might start a second playthrough, now that I'm aware of what I can expect and select my troops accordingly.  I selected at least one of every type to find out what upgrades are available on the first round (spiders and bats for example are very situational and need careful consideration, it might be better to include an allpurpose unit like a mage or succubus instead etc.)

What I like is that the two campaigns favour a different playstyle....As orcs you have a very solid melee wall and try to snipe the opposing frontline with hypnotize to turn their own troops against them....As succubus you flood the enemy with summons and snipe with fireballs, not caring if it hits your own summons.

Loved both ways:)

Oh and a small tip, hidden stashes are automatically detected, as soon as one of your troops can reach the spot...so to find anything (not every map has secrets), walk a fast runner all around the map before leaving the battle(use of t-key was very helpful here).

reviewText:
A nice little game with really nice developers. They are active in the steam forums and answer questions and listen to your recommandations and critics. Now you have even the chance to give them input, what you would like to see in Age of Fear 3.

About the game itself:
The fights are challenging and sometimes quite hard if you play on Experienced- or Master-Difficulty. Even experienced turn-based players should try and easiest mode first, because some of the mechanics need some experience to really understand them or at least very good reading of the tutorial informations given. Keeping your units alive is probably the most important about this game, to evolve them in the way you wish them to be. Also you should keep an eye on wich units get the exp, to speed up leveling of specific units.

Yes, the story is textwalled, but I enjoyed to read those and I liked how the storyline evolved, at least the one I played through so far. There are even slight possibilities to chose wich arc of story line you wish to follow. If they even could change the ending, I can't tell so far, but I don't think so. But they offer you different battles and items and perhaps even special units.

If you play, you should be aware, some of those fights you have to lose. So if an opponent looks far stronger than you, don't get frustrated and give up. Your loss has to be then probably and offers perhaps some new units, you couldn't get your hands on otherwise.

And yes, the graphics aren't the best of the best, but they aren't the important stuff. The combat is important and the AI is well programmed and lets you suffer, if you don't plan your actions well. So if you like a challenging old school game support these indies.

P. S.: And no, you don't really play only evil ones. Yes, you can play an orcish story line (wich I can't argue about much so far) and a demon story line, but the demon is far from pure evil but selfish and manipulative for sure. ;)

This game has a very rough feel to it and plan on using your keyboard instead of mouse for almost every action.  It is also, not very intuitive.  Plan on reading and remembering the _HUGE_ pile of documentation when starting a new game or you will be helplessly lost.

My one primary complaint is that I couldn't find a way to make the lead character to quit saying her lines everytime she did something.  They were deliberatly loaded with inuendo, and became very annoying after hearing them multiple times.

So it comes down to a yes or no rating on Steam.  I'll say yes, but only if you are aware of what you are getting into first.  If you are expecting a modern game you will be dissapointed, otherwise, enjoy.
